findings.title: RC - Redundant Code
findings.description: The variable `bpEnabled` is initialized to `false` and is never modified elsewhere in the contract, making the condition `bpEnabled && !BPDisabledForever` always evaluate to `false`, rendering the code inside the if statement redundant.

findings.title: MEE - Missing Events Emission
findings.description: The contract performs actions and state mutations from external methods that do not result in the emission of events.

findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract updates the state of excluded addresses even if their current state is the same as the one passed as an argument, resulting in redundant storage writes.

findings.title: DEE - Duplicate Event Emission
findings.description: The contract could emits the two events with the same data. As a result event duplication is created.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to decrease gas consumption of the corresponding transaction.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not adhere to the Solidity style guide's naming conventions, which can affect readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L08 - Tautology or Contradiction
findings.description: A tautology is a logical statement that is always true, regardless of the values of its variables. A contradiction is a logical statement that is always false, regardless of the values of its variables.

findings.title: L11 - Unnecessary Boolean equality
findings.description: Boolean equality is unnecessary when comparing two boolean values.

findings.title: L16 - Validate Variable Setters
findings.description: The contract performs operations on variables configured with user-supplied input without proper checks for zero values, leading to potential problems during execution.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.
